--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@y...> wrote:
> I'm interested in exploring the limits of what ANNs
> can do, so my next problem is going to be one that's
> well suited for the normal computing paradigm, but not
> well suited for an ANN.  This problem requires short
> term memory, and use of what is stored there, so an
> MLP can't do the job.  It must be some kind of
> recurrent ANN.  The problem is to play the game of
> concentration.  That's the card game where all the
> cards are spread face down and each player gets to
> turn over two cards.  If they are a pair he keeps them
> and gets another turn.  Otherwise they go face down
> again.  When humans play it its mainly a test of
> memory, although if your memory is perfect there is
> some strategy involved.  (see Sci. Am. Oct. 1991)
> 

Hi Mitchell, concentration does sound like a very
interesting problem for an ANN.  It is probably
quite difficult since it involves long term 
accurate and discrete memory.  But the input representaiton,
i.e. how you represent the cards to the network,
is probably a major issue.  And it's not clear what
the right way would be, so it needs careful consideration
since some representations are likely impossible for an ANN to
deal with.  But I think it's quite an interesting experiment,
and I hope someone tries it out.  I am unfortunately 
involved in plugging NEAT into too many experiments at
the present time, but if you put your code in the
files section of this board, hopefully someone will take
interest.  If I find time I might play with it myself.

ken
